title: 104_s125
content: The Act may be cited as the "United Nations 50th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and includes specifications for the coin. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under the Act. All coins minted under the Act are considered numismatic items according to the United States Code. The Secretary will obtain gold for minting coins under this Act through existing legal provisions, and silver will be sourced only from stockpiles established under a specific Act. Design requirements for coins minted under this Act include being emblematic of the United Nations, featuring the opening words of the UN Charter, and inscriptions of value, year, "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the United Nations Association of the United States of America. The design for coins minted under this Act must be emblematic of the United Nations and include the opening words of the UN Charter. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the United Nations Association of the United States of America, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins authorized under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Bullion Depository at West Point. The Secretary may issue these coins only between June 26, 1995, and December 31, 2002. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges will apply to all sales. The $5 coin is priced at $25 per coin, while the $1 coin is priced at $5 per coin. SEC. 7 of the Act waives procurement regulations for goods and services needed for Act implementation, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 addresses the distribution of surcharges. SEC. 8 of the Act mandates that all surcharges from coin sales be promptly paid to the United Nations Association of the United States for educational activities. The Comptroller General has the right to audit the Association's expenditures. SEC. 9 of the Act ensures that minting and issuing coins will not cost the government. Payment for coins must be made in full, with satisfactory security or guarantees.
